<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 121, 636, 145]]<|/det|> # Cambridge International AS & A Level <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 170, 195, 201]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NAME <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 221, 175, 250]]<|/det|> CENTRE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[210, 210, 425, 260]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[620, 220, 720, 250]]<|/det|> CANDIDATE NUMBER <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 210, 905, 255]]<|/det|> <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 276, 178, 293]]<|/det|> ## PHYSICS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[832, 277, 905, 293]]<|/det|> 9702/32 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 301, 361, 317]]<|/det|> Paper 3 Advanced Practical Skills 2 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 301, 905, 317]]<|/det|> May/June 2020 <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[841, 326, 905, 341]]<|/det|> 2 hours <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 355, 393, 371]]<|/det|> You must answer on the question paper. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 384, 700, 401]]<|/det|> You will need: The materials and apparatus listed in the confidential instructions <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 222, 434]]<|/det|> ## INSTRUCTIONS <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 890, 607]]<|/det|> INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You will be allowed to work with the apparatus for a maximum of 1 hour for each question.- You should record all your observations in the spaces provided in the question paper as soon as these observations are made.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units. <|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 634, 220, 650]]<|/det|> ## INFORMATION <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 651, 728, 683]]<|/det|> INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 40.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ]. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 702, 905, 851]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 867, 712, 884]]<|/det|> This document has 12 pages. Blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 739, 89]]<|/det|>
You may not need to use all of the materials provided.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 102, 96, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 102, 920, 135]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate a pendulum made from a wooden strip with masses fixed at one end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 149, 146, 166]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 149, 589, 166]]<|/det|>
Some of the apparatus has been assembled for you.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 180, 178, 198]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 180, 747, 198]]<|/det|>
Pass the nail through the hole in the strip furthest from the masses.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 212, 180, 230]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 212, 472, 230]]<|/det|>
Fix the nail securely in the clamp.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 243, 180, 261]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 243, 680, 261]]<|/det|>
Complete the set-up of the apparatus as shown in Fig. 1.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 272, 845, 597]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[406, 610, 591, 628]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 1.1 (not to scale)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 642, 178, 660]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 642, 902, 660]]<|/det|>
The hooks at the ends of the springs should pass through one of the holes in the strip.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 672, 920, 705]]<|/det|>
Position the stands so that the coiled section of each spring is of approximate length \(6\mathrm{cm}\) and the strip is vertical.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 719, 178, 737]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 719, 836, 737]]<|/det|>
The distance along the strip between the nail and the hole with the hooks is \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 750, 384, 767]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(d\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 812, 920, 831]]<|/det|>
<form>d = .................................................... cm [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 918, 89]]<|/det|>
● Move the bottom of the strip towards one of the stands and release it so that it oscillates.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 102, 180, 120]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 747, 120]]<|/det|>
Take measurements to determine the period \(T\) of these oscillations.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 285, 920, 304]]<|/det|>
<form>T = .................................................... s [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 71, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
Move the hooks to a different hole in the strip. Measure \(d\) and \(T\). Repeat until you have six sets of values of \(d\) and \(T\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 109, 751, 135]]<|/det|>
Record your results in a table. Include values of \(d^2\) and \(\frac{1}{T^2}\) in your table.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 535, 920, 553]]<|/det|>
<mark>[9]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 567, 144, 585]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[146, 560, 175, 583]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 556, 660, 587]]<|/det|>
Plot a graph of \(\frac{1}{T^2}\) on the \(y\)-axis against \(d^2\) on the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 565, 920, 584]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 597, 180, 616]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 596, 457, 616]]<|/det|>
Draw the straight line of best fit.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 597, 920, 616]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 628, 180, 647]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 628, 608, 647]]<|/det|>
Determine the gradient and \(y\)-intercept of this line.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 861, 917, 880]]<|/det|>
<form>gradient = ................................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[475, 892, 917, 910]]<|/det|>
<form>y-intercept = ............................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 907, 920, 925]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[260, 72, 737, 89]]<|/det|>
**You may not need to use all of the materials provided.**

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 102, 96, 121]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 102, 831, 120]]<|/det|>
In this experiment, you will investigate the bending of a rod under a compressive force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 146, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 920, 166]]<|/det|>
You are provided with two thin rods. Measure and record the length \(L\) and diameter \(d\) of the **longer** rod.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 193, 917, 211]]<|/det|>
\[L = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 240, 920, 257]]<|/det|>
\[d = ....................................................\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 256, 920, 275]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 288, 146, 306]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 288, 740, 306]]<|/det|>
Assemble the apparatus as shown in Fig. 2.1 using the longer rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 303, 871, 320]]<|/det|>
Position the ends of the rod in the shallow holes in the wooden strip and the block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[123, 330, 875, 635]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 653, 536, 670]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 685, 178, 702]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 685, 920, 717]]<|/det|>
Adjust the apparatus so that the rod is vertical and the wooden strip is parallel to the bench.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 732, 173, 749]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 732, 920, 764]]<|/det|>
The distance between the nail and the top of the rod is \(x\) and the distance between the nail and the string loop is \(y\), as shown in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 778, 435, 794]]<|/det|>
Measure and record \(x\) and \(y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 808, 917, 825]]<|/det|>
<form>x = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 839, 920, 856]]<|/det|>
<form>y = ..........................................................

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[893, 854, 920, 871]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[161, 72, 920, 104]]<|/det|>
● Slowly pull the newton meter down until the rod bends in the middle by approximately \(1 \text{cm}\), as shown in Fig. 2.2.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 114, 819, 420]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 435, 534, 454]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 2.2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 467, 180, 485]]<|/det|>
<label>●</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 467, 752, 486]]<|/det|>
Record the force \(F_{\mathrm{m}}\) needed to bend the rod by approximately \(1\mathrm{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[539, 590, 922, 609]]<|/det|>
<form>F_{\mathrm{m}} = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 621, 146, 640]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 621, 787, 640]]<|/det|>
Estimate the percentage uncertainty in your value of \(F_{\mathrm{m}}\). Show your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[373, 776, 922, 794]]<|/det|>
<form>percentage uncertainty = .................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 146, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>(h)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 630, 91]]<|/det|>
It is suggested that the relationship between \(F, L\) and \(d\) is

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 94, 546, 125]]<|/det|>
\[E = \frac{64FL^2}{\pi^3d^4}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 133, 343, 151]]<|/det|>
where \(E\) is a constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 163, 183, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 163, 547, 183]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 432, 767, 451]]<|/det|>
